data.text:
The winter storm warning has changed into a winter weather advisory, as of Monday night.

St. Joseph County, along with many other counties in our area, saw off-and-on snow flurries.

That type of snowfall is typical for a lake effect set-up, but the strong wind in many areas caused many problems.

South Bend Police Department said, there were 27 crashes the SBPD responded to from 7am-10pm on Monday night.

One driver says, he wasn't the happiest about this snow, but this will allow new drivers to gain experience.

"I wish it wouldn’t have come at all to be honest with you after living here for so long you get used to it. The new kids of course haven't experienced it too much I do have a 17-year-old son who’s driving for his first time in the snow." saidRichard Warfield -Lives in Osceola."

Most of our area was under an alert for winter weather in anticipation for lake effect snow and slick roads.

Berrien County first started seeing this lake effect snow Monday morning and it will continue through Monday night.

Those lake effect snow bands and the strong winds will cause issues.

The National Weather Service issued a WINTER STORM WARNING for Berrien and Cass Counties in Michigan, and Elkhart and eastern St. Joseph Counties in . A WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY was issued for northern LaPorte, western St. Joseph (IN), northern Kosciusko, all of Marshall, LaGrange and St. Joseph (MI) Counties.These alerts will be in effect until 4 AM EST Tuesday.

One minute it's snowing and blowing so hard that it's hard to see and the next the sun is brightly shining.

In Niles, there's a couple inches of snow on the ground in most areas.

WSBT spoke with the Berrien County Road Department. They have several trucks on the roads spreading salt, but one of their biggest battles is with the blowing snow as it reduces visibility at times.

We also talked with to a spokesman for the Michigan Department of Transportation.

He said U.S. 31 and I-94 are in pretty good shape, but they have had accidents throughout the day.

Plow crews are going to be on the roads all night until the lake effect is expected to taper off early tomorrow morning.

Low visibility and lake effect snow bands caused issues for drivers in Berrien County late Monday morning.

In Elkhart, the snow itself isn't the main issue rather the very strong winds.

The snow appears to be sticking to the grass but is still creating some slippery patches on the roads.

The wet conditions on the roads could cause problems as the temperature drops.

The lane has since re-opened.

Bands of heavy lake effect snow will continue to impact some through the afternoon and into the evening.

Most areas will see up to about 2" of snow, but under the heaviest snow bands we could see 4-6" or more.

Roads will become snow covered, and roads that were just wet in the morning will become slick as temperatures fall into the 20s. This will make driving in the afternoon and evening a bit difficult.

Crews were out early Monday pretreating the roads and laying down salt to help with road conditions in the later half of the day, but roads are still expected to be very slick in spots.

The snow will also be blown around by very strong winds, which could lead to reduced visibility at times.

If you want to see what roads look like before you head out the door, .

Not only will we be dealing with the snow, Monday will be very chilly thanks to strong winds.

Winds are expected to gust to around 40 miles per hour in the afternoon. While actual air temperatures will be in the upper 20s to low 30s, we'll be feeling like the teens at times!

The snow will start to come to an end overnight, though roads could still be slippery Tuesday morning.

What snow we have accumulated will not stick around forever - we will be back to the low 40s by mid-week.
